content.question: A GRAPHING CALCULATOR IS REQUIRED FOR THIS QUESTION. You are permitted to use your calculator to solve an equation, find the derivative of a function at a point, or calculate the value of a definite integral. However, you must clearly indicate the setup of your question, namely the equation, function, or integral you are using. If you use other built-in features or programs, you must show the mathematical steps necessary to produce your results. Your work must be expressed in standard mathematical notation rather than calculator syntax. Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit. Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point. Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. <math alttext="The figure presents a 3 row table, with 4 columns of data. The heading for row 1 is “x.” The heading for row 2 is “f of x.” The heading for row 3 is “f prime of x.” The data in the table are as follows. Column 1. x is negative 3. f of x is 5. f prime of x is negative 2. Column 2. x is 0. f of x is negative 1. f prime of x is 4. Column 3. x is 3. f of x is 2. f prime of x is 0. Column 4. x is 4. f of x is 7. f prime of x is 1."><mstyle><mrow><mtable columnlines="solid" columnspacing="0.0em" columnwidth="3em 0.05em 3em 3em 3em 3em" frame="solid" framespacing="0.0em 0ex" rowlines="solid" rowspacing="0.05ex" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><mi>x</mi></mtd><mtd><mspace depth="1.0ex" height="2.5ex" width="0.0em"></mspace></mtd><mtd><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>3</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>4</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd><mspace depth="1.0ex" height="2.5ex" width="0.0em"></mspace></mtd><mtd><mn>5</mn></mtd><mtd><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mtd><mtd><mn>2</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>7</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd><mspace depth="1.0ex" height="2.5ex" width="0.0em"></mspace></mtd><mtd><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mtd><mtd><mn>4</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>1</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math> The table above gives values of a twice-differentiable function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and its first derivative <math alttext="f prime "><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> for selected values of <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Let <math alttext="g"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be the function defined by <math alttext="g of x equals, f of, open parenthesis, 2 x minus, x squared, close parenthesis"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) What is the value of <math alttext="g prime of negative 1"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> ?

frqParts.text: A GRAPHING CALCULATOR IS REQUIRED FOR THIS QUESTION. You are permitted to use your calculator to solve an equation, find the derivative of a function at a point, or calculate the value of a definite integral. However, you must clearly indicate the setup of your question, namely the equation, function, or integral you are using. If you use other built-in features or programs, you must show the mathematical steps necessary to produce your results. Your work must be expressed in standard mathematical notation rather than calculator syntax. Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit. Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point. Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. <math alttext="The figure presents a 3 row table, with 4 columns of data. The heading for row 1 is “x.” The heading for row 2 is “f of x.” The heading for row 3 is “f prime of x.” The data in the table are as follows. Column 1. x is negative 3. f of x is 5. f prime of x is negative 2. Column 2. x is 0. f of x is negative 1. f prime of x is 4. Column 3. x is 3. f of x is 2. f prime of x is 0. Column 4. x is 4. f of x is 7. f prime of x is 1."><mstyle><mrow><mtable columnlines="solid" columnspacing="0.0em" columnwidth="3em 0.05em 3em 3em 3em 3em" frame="solid" framespacing="0.0em 0ex" rowlines="solid" rowspacing="0.05ex" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><mi>x</mi></mtd><mtd><mspace depth="1.0ex" height="2.5ex" width="0.0em"></mspace></mtd><mtd><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>3</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>4</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd><mspace depth="1.0ex" height="2.5ex" width="0.0em"></mspace></mtd><mtd><mn>5</mn></mtd><mtd><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mtd><mtd><mn>2</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>7</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd><mspace depth="1.0ex" height="2.5ex" width="0.0em"></mspace></mtd><mtd><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mtd><mtd><mn>4</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>1</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math> The table above gives values of a twice-differentiable function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and its first derivative <math alttext="f prime "><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> for selected values of <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Let <math alttext="g"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be the function defined by <math alttext="g of x equals, f of, open parenthesis, 2 x minus, x squared, close parenthesis"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) What is the value of <math alttext="g prime of negative 1"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> ?

(b) It is known that <math alttext="g double prime of 0, equals 0"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>″</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. What is the value of <math alttext="f double prime of 0 "><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>″</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> ?

(c) Is there a value <math alttext="c"><mstyle><mrow><mi>c</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, for <math alttext="0 is less than c is less than 3"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo><</mo><mi>c</mi><mo><</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, such that <math alttext="g of c, equals 2 "><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></math> ? Justify your answer.

(d) Let <math alttext="h"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be the function with first derivative given by <math alttext="h prime of x, equals, 4 x times e to the x power"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>. At what value of <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> in the interval <math alttext="0 less than or equal to x, less than or equal to 4 "><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> does the instantaneous rate of change of <math alttext="h"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> equal the average rate of change of <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> over the interval <math alttext="0 less than or equal to x, less than or equal to 4"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ?

topic.text: 1.16: Working with the Intermediate Value Theorem (IVT)

skill.text: Skill 1.C: Identify an appropriate mathematical rule or procedure based on the classification of a given expression (e.g., Use the chain rule to find the derivative of a composite function).
